A random vector X = (X₁, X₂)ᵀ has mean μ = (1, 2)ᵀ and covariance matrix Σ = [[4, 1], [1, 2]]. Define the quadratic form Q = XᵀAX where A = [[1, 0], [0, 1]] (the identity matrix). Using the formula E[XᵀAX] = tr(AΣ) + μᵀAμ, compute E[Q].

Consider a system where a random signal vector s = (s₁, s₂)ᵀ with E[s] = (3, -2)ᵀ passes through two consecutive linear filters. The first filter is represented by matrix F₁ = [[1, 1], [2, -1]] and the second by F₂ = [[0, 2], [1, 1]]. The output is y = F₂F₁s + n, where n is a noise vector with E[n] = (1, -1)ᵀ. Find the expected value of the L₁ norm of y, i.e., E[|y₁|] + E[|y₂|], assuming E[|yᵢ|] = |E[yᵢ]| (the expected values of y₁ and y₂ have the same sign as their realizations almost surely).

In triangle ABC, points D, E, and F lie on sides BC, CA, and AB respectively. Three students make the following statements:

Student 1: "AD, BE, and CF are concurrent at a point P, and the ratio AP:PD = 3:1."
Student 2: "The ratio BD:DC = 2:1 and AF:FB = 1:2."
Student 3: "The ratio CE:EA = 1:1."

It is known that exactly one student is lying. Given that AD, BE, and CF are indeed concurrent, determine the sum of all possible values of BD/DC when expressed as a fraction in lowest terms. If the possible values are p₁/q₁ and p₂/q₂, give your answer as p₁ + q₁ + p₂ + q₂.

Four points A, B, C, D lie on a circle with center O. A geometry student makes three claims:

Claim I: "ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral with AB = 13, BC = 14, CD = 15, and DA = 12."
Claim II: "The diagonals AC and BD intersect at point P, and triangle APB has area 72."
Claim III: "The circumradius of triangle ABC equals the circumradius of triangle ACD."

Exactly two of these claims are true, and one is false. The false claim, when corrected by changing exactly one number in it, becomes consistent with the other two true claims. If the corrected number in the false claim is N, find N.

In a coordinate plane, five points P₁, P₂, P₃, P₄, P₅ are positioned such that each lies on a circle centered at the origin. Five oracles make statements:

Oracle A: "P₁ is at distance 5 from the origin and P₂ is at distance 12 from P₁."
Oracle B: "P₂, P₃, P₄ are collinear."
Oracle C: "Triangle P₁P₃P₅ is equilateral with side length 5√3."
Oracle D: "The five points all lie on the same circle of radius 5."
Oracle E: "P₄ is the reflection of P₂ over the line OP₃."

Exactly one oracle speaks falsely. If all five points indeed lie on a common circle, find the radius of this circle.

Triangle XYZ has integer side lengths. Three geometers provide information:

Geometer 1: "The incircle of XYZ has radius 6, and the triangle's area is 126."
Geometer 2: "Side XY has length 13, and the altitude from Z to XY has length 18."
Geometer 3: "The circumradius of triangle XYZ is 65/4."

At most one geometer is incorrect. Using the valid statements, determine the perimeter of triangle XYZ.

A quadrilateral PQRS is inscribed in a circle. Four witnesses report measurements:

Witness 1: "PQ = 7 and RS = 11."
Witness 2: "QR = 8 and PS = 10."
Witness 3: "Diagonal PR = 13 and diagonal QS = 14."
Witness 4: "The area of PQRS is 84."

It is determined that exactly one witness gave a false report, and the three truthful reports are mutually consistent with PQRS being a valid cyclic quadrilateral. The false witness reported a value that differs from the true value by an integer amount d. Find d.

A factory produces widgets at a rate that follows a peculiar pattern: on day n, the factory produces exactly φ(n) widgets, where φ is Euler's totient function. The factory operates for 30 consecutive days starting from day 1. A quality inspector checks widgets at a constant rate of 8 widgets per hour and works 6 hours per day. After the 30-day production period ends, how many complete days will the inspector need to check all the widgets produced, assuming the inspector starts checking only after all production is complete?

Two machines stamp serial numbers on products. Machine A stamps products with serial numbers that are perfect squares, processing one product every 3 minutes. Machine B stamps products with serial numbers that are perfect cubes, processing one product every 4 minutes. Both machines start simultaneously at 8:00 AM and run until 5:00 PM. A supervisor notices that some products get stamped by both machines (when the serial number is both a perfect square and a perfect cube). If each double-stamped product requires 15 minutes of correction time, and a technician works on corrections at a rate of one product at a time starting the next day, how many minutes total will the technician spend on corrections for all products that were double-stamped during that workday?

A courier delivers packages to houses numbered 1 through 200 on a street. The courier's speed varies based on number theory: when approaching house number n, the courier travels at a rate of d(n) meters per minute, where d(n) is the number of positive divisors of n. Each house is exactly 100 meters from the previous house. The courier starts at house 1 and must visit houses whose numbers are multiples of 6 but not multiples of 12. Calculate the total time in minutes the courier spends traveling between consecutive houses on this specific route (not counting time at houses), starting from house 1 to the first target house, then between each pair of consecutive target houses.

A water tank fills at a variable rate determined by the time in minutes: during minute t (where t = 1, 2, 3, ...), the tank receives exactly gcd(t, 60) liters of water. The tank has a capacity of 1000 liters and starts empty. A drain at the bottom removes water at a constant rate of 2 liters per minute, starting from minute 1. At the end of which minute will the tank first contain more than 500 liters of water?

A cryptographer encodes messages using prime numbers. She processes p characters per hour when working on the pth prime number in her sequence. Starting with the 1st prime (2), she spends exactly one hour on each prime before moving to the next. She needs to encode a document with 500 characters. Her assistant simultaneously decodes at a constant rate of 15 characters per hour, but can only decode characters that have already been encoded. The assistant starts working at the same time as the cryptographer. After how many complete hours will the assistant have decoded at least 200 characters?

A mathematics club surveyed its 40 members about their participation in three competitions: Algebra (A), Geometry (G), and Number Theory (N). The results showed: 25 participated in Algebra, 22 in Geometry, 18 in Number Theory, 12 in both Algebra and Geometry, 10 in both Algebra and Number Theory, 8 in both Geometry and Number Theory, and 5 participated in all three. After verifying the data, the club advisor noticed that one of the following numbers doesn't fit with the others when calculating the number of students who participated in exactly one competition: {8, 9, 5, 7}. Using set theory principles, identify which number is the outlier that does NOT represent students in exactly one competition.

Consider five sets defined as follows: Set P = {multiples of 6 less than 50}, Set Q = {perfect squares less than 50}, Set R = {factors of 48}, Set S = {prime numbers less than 20}, Set T = {even numbers from 10 to 30}. Calculate |P ∩ R|, |Q ∩ T|, |S ∩ P|, and |R ∩ Q|. One of these intersection cardinalities is an outlier compared to the pattern formed by the others. Which cardinality value is the outlier?

In a school of 200 students, data was collected about membership in clubs: Drama (D), Music (M), and Art (A). Given: |D| = 85, |M| = 90, |A| = 75, |D ∩ M| = 40, |D ∩ A| = 35, |M ∩ A| = 30, |D ∩ M ∩ A| = 15, and students in no club = 20. When computing the number of students in exactly two clubs for each pair, the values obtained are compared. The set of results is {25, 20, 15, 22}. Using the inclusion-exclusion principle, determine which value in this set is NOT a valid count of students belonging to exactly two of these clubs.

Let U = {1, 2, 3, 4, ..., 30} be the universal set. Define: A = {x ∈ U : x is divisible by 3}, B = {x ∈ U : x is divisible by 5}, C = {x ∈ U : x is a prime number}. A student calculated the following cardinalities: |A' ∩ B| = 4, |B' ∩ C| = 9, |A ∩ C| = 2, |(A ∪ B)' ∩ C| = 6. One of these four calculated values is incorrect and represents an outlier. Identify the incorrect cardinality value.

A survey of 150 high school students examined their preferences for three streaming services: Netflix (N), Hulu (H), and Disney+ (D). The symmetric differences were calculated: |N Δ H| = 75, |H Δ D| = 80, |N Δ D| = 70. Additionally, |N ∩ H ∩ D| = 10 and |N ∪ H ∪ D| = 140. A student claimed the individual set sizes are |N| = 65, |H| = 72, |D| = 58, and |N ∩ H| = 28. Using the properties of symmetric difference and set operations, determine which of the four claimed values {65, 72, 58, 28} is the outlier that contradicts the given information.

A game show contestant spins a wheel divided into 8 equal sections numbered 1 through 8. After spinning, they can either keep the number shown as their score (in dollars) or choose to spin again. If they spin again, they must accept the second result. However, if the second spin lands on a number less than or equal to their first spin, they lose everything and score 0. What is the optimal strategy's expected value in dollars?

Five cards are drawn without replacement from a standard 52-card deck. For each pair of cards that share the same suit among the five drawn cards, you earn $1. For example, if three cards are hearts and two are spades, you earn $3 (from the three heart pairs) + $1 (from the spade pair) = $4. What is the expected value of your earnings in dollars?

In a classroom of 20 students, each student is randomly assigned a locker number from 1 to 20 (each number used exactly once). A student is called 'lucky' if their locker number shares at least one prime factor with their student ID number (students are numbered 1-20, and student 1 is considered to share no prime factors). What is the expected number of lucky students?

Alice and Bob play a game where they take turns rolling a fair six-sided die, with Alice going first. The first person to roll a 6 wins the game and receives a prize equal to the total number of rolls made during the entire game (in dollars). If Alice wins, what is the expected value of the prize she receives, given that she wins?

A bag contains 4 red marbles and 6 blue marbles. You draw marbles one at a time without replacement until you draw a red marble, at which point the game ends. Your score equals the number of blue marbles drawn before the red marble, squared. What is the expected value of your score?

A quality control inspector at a factory checks products at a rate of 45 items per hour. Historical data shows that 3.2% of all products are defective. On Monday, the inspector worked for 6 hours and found 7 defective items. On Tuesday, she worked for 8 hours and found 11 defective items. Calculate the probability that the combined number of defective items found over both days differs from the expected number by more than 2 items, assuming defects follow a binomial distribution. Round your answer to four decimal places.

A hospital emergency room receives patients at an average rate of 12 patients per hour during peak times (6 PM to midnight) and 5 patients per hour during off-peak times (midnight to 6 AM). Each patient requires an average of 25 minutes of treatment time. If the ER has 6 treatment bays and operates from 6 PM to 6 AM, what is the probability that at least one patient will have to wait during a randomly selected 15-minute interval during peak hours, assuming patient arrivals follow a Poisson distribution?

A website experiences traffic at a rate of 200 visitors per hour. Each visitor has a 4% probability of making a purchase, and among those who purchase, 15% buy premium items while the rest buy standard items. Premium items generate $85 profit each, while standard items generate $22 profit each. If the website operates 18 hours per day, calculate the expected daily profit and then determine the probability that the actual number of premium purchases in a single hour exceeds 2. Round the probability to four decimal places.

Two machines in a factory produce widgets. Machine A produces 80 widgets per hour with a defect rate of 2.5%, while Machine B produces 120 widgets per hour with a defect rate of 4%. Both machines operate for 5 hours. If a quality inspector randomly selects 50 widgets from the combined production, what is the expected number of defective widgets in the sample, and what is the standard deviation of this number? Give your answer as 'expected, standard deviation' rounded to two decimal places each.

A call center receives calls at a rate that varies by time: 30 calls per hour from 9 AM to 12 PM, 45 calls per hour from 12 PM to 2 PM, and 25 calls per hour from 2 PM to 5 PM. Each call handler can process calls at a rate of 8 calls per hour. If 12% of all calls result in a sale, and each sale generates $45 in revenue, calculate the minimum number of call handlers needed to ensure that the probability of having more than 5 calls waiting at any given moment during peak hours (12 PM to 2 PM) is less than 10%, using the Poisson approximation.
